title: Hurricane Dorian is on track to bring historic coastal flooding to the Carolinas
text:
Hurricane Dorian had originally been advertised as a huge threat to the Florida coastline, but it seems more likely now that it will be remembered both for the devastation it caused in the Bahamas, as well as the storm-surge flooding it might bring to the Carolinas.

Water levels are already rising along the coasts of Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina. Some locations may see as much as five to eight feet of storm-surge flooding, which will come on top of already high astronomical high tides. Storm surge refers to the storm-driven rise in ocean water above normally dry land.

Hurricane Dorian is a particularly acute threat to the coastline because of the storm’s expanding wind field, with hurricane-force winds extending 70 miles from the storm’s center, and tropical storm-force winds reaching 175 miles from the eye.

Here's the latest #Dorian storm surge forecast from this morning. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide. For more details see https://t.co/tW4KeFW0gB pic.twitter.com/FnozVJ0eqh — National Hurricane Center (@NHC_Atlantic) September 4, 2019

Sea-level rise caused by human-caused global warming and land subsidence will exacerbate coastal flooding in locations such as Charleston, S.C., and Wilmington, N.C. If Charleston were to see a four-to-seven-foot surge at the time of high tide, large parts of downtown would be flooded, and the event could go down in history as the second-highest water level on record there, behind only Hurricane Hugo. That storm struck in 1989 as a Category 4.

The fact that Dorian may cause a comparable flood 30 years after that far stronger storm is an indication of how much easier it is to flood coastal areas, thanks to rising sea levels.

Sea-level rise provides storm surge with a higher baseline on which to ride, much like a game of basketball played on a court that’s gradually rising, allowing players to score far more slam dunks than they normally would. Sunny day flooding has become an increasingly common occurrence in Charleston during astronomical high tides.

The @NWSWPC has issued a High Risk area for flash flooding over eastern South Carolina & SE North Carolina for Thursday due to #Dorian. Very heavy rainfall totals of up 15 inches are possible. For more details see https://t.co/tW4KeFW0gB or https://t.co/LsPr5wAy5h pic.twitter.com/Ngp4I0mMQ6 — National Hurricane Center (@NHC_Atlantic) September 4, 2019

From 1900 to 2018, sea level has risen by 1.26 feet in Charleston, with an annual increase averaging 0.13 inches per year. That may not seem like much, but in a low-lying, highly populated area, every inch of sea-level rise matters.

The heavy rains anticipated to fall in the coastal Carolinas will make the situation worse for shoreline communities, as a foot or more of rain falling in a short period will make drainage back to the ocean more difficult, especially at times of high tide. Charleston saw significant flooding during Hurricanes Matthew and Irma, and depending on its exact arrival and forecast track, Hurricane Dorian could exceed those levels during the high tide early Thursday at 1 a.m., before the storm makes its closest pass.

Major flooding in Charleston begins at 8 feet, and as of Wednesday morning, NOAA was forecasting a peak tide height (storm surge plus background tide) of 10.3 feet for the early Thursday morning high tide. The subsequent high tide may see more significant flooding, depending on the timing of the switch to offshore winds once the center of Dorian passes to the north of Charleston.

According to Sarah Watson, a coastal climate and resilience specialist with the South Carolina Sea Grant Consortium as well as the Carolinas Integrated Sciences and Assessments, water was already coming out of the drains on some Charleston roads as of midday Wednesday. In an interview, she noted that the combination of high astronomical tides plus heavy rains, will keep water levels elevated for an extended period.



Observed and forecast water levels in Charleston, S.C. (NOAA)

If the water level reaches 10.3 feet, as is predicted, it would flood many areas with potentially at least 2 feet of water, including the lower-lying historical areas and the medical district.

Assuming they flood again, many of these houses will have flooded for the 4th time in 5 years. “A lot of people are expecting substantial flooding,” Watson said.



Projected flooding for a 10.3-foot projected storm surge in Charleston, S.C. This map does not include flooding due to heavy rainfall. (The Lowcountry Hazards Center at the College of Charleston, Dr. Norman S. Levine in collaboration with the South Carolina Sea Grant Consortium)

“One of the things I’m looking at, you know, is people are tired… You’re starting to see that in people’s conversations and faces that they’re weary and tired" from repeated bouts of coastal flooding. Unable to elevate their historic structures, have resorted to trying out their own flood protection barriers.

Now the big fancy tiger dam. This is a $8000 set of tubes filled with water. The owners can’t really elevate the house, so they bought this just in time for last year and have set it back up again. Inside they’ve still sand-bagged the areas at risk (the sub basement.) pic.twitter.com/sRZkgBvhs0 — Sarah Watson (@BySarahWatson) September 4, 2019

Other locations will also see damaging coastal flooding, including the area around Savannah, Ga., and large stretches of the North Carolina coastline.

In Fort Pulaski, which is about 20 miles east of Savannah along the Savannah River, the water level is forecast to reach major flood level of 11.5 feet, which would rank as the third-highest on record, trailing the levels reached during Hurricanes Matthew (12.56 feet) and Irma (12.24 feet).

In Wilmington, N.C., major coastal flooding is expected. Hurricane Florence cut off access to that city last year from a combination of heavy rains and storm-surge flooding, perhaps making people there more aware (and wary) of the risks.

Flooding will be a concern along the Outer Banks of North Carolina, too, where beach erosion can reshape the coast during storms of this magnitude.

Jason Samenow contributed to this report.
description: Hurricane Dorian's most formidable weapon as it pushes into the Carolinas will be storm-surge flooding, which could be historic in some locations.
